title: Can 1 partner of an LLC freeze a business account? how is payroll made if the account is frozen???????
question: my husband has 1 partner in his llc business and they are in disagreement as to what to do with the company and his partner froze the business account and we are now unable to make payroll. The company is loosing money partly because of the economy and the of marketing effort on his partner but his partner seems to disagree on fault. Anyways, the office lease is killing them and causing a loss each month. My husband just found another business to sublease our space so we could get out of our lease obligation and shut the business down without having to payout the lease. His partner feels that he should get his full amount of funds back with no loss so he froze the account. What are your thoughts on what to do now, we will be looking for an attorney but what could we do in the meantime??
answers:
It appears that, as a practical matter, there is little you can do on your own.

You need to retain a business litigator ASAP.

Yikes this is bad; I don't know what you mean by froze, but if you are BOTH signers on the business account you BOTH can do anything with it. Practically speaking the bank should require both signatures if there are conflicting instructions, so give the bank conflicting instructions. (by way of example, your husband if he is a signer, can I assume "unfreeze the account and take out all the money, as can, unfortunately the other partner. I would go right to the bank and see what they can and will and will not do with whomever has signing authority. And do not deposit any more checks int here or allow the partner to do so if he has all the control.
The sublease sounds like the sublease will save everyone's behind, but our partner doesn't get this. So perhaps a sit down meeting with a trusted 3rd party business person will make sense, and quick.
As for the future, yes you definitely need at least a couple hours attorney paid time for strategy discussions on what to do with the LLC, the debts, etc. What partner is doing may be unlawful (not paying employees, both of you will be personally liable in the long run), or perhaps he has a legitimate business transaction, but from what you write, sounds like he is going to cause more problems before it gets better. You need to negotiate a mutually workable break up asap, but employees need to get paid, or they will take you all to labor court. You need to lay off employees asap to cut off further potential liability, and since you are closing down the business anyway.
Too much to go over in this forum, contact a local experienced business attorney.
There is too much going on here to give you a simple answer. You really need to hire a local business attorney to protect you. You can use Avvo's "find a lawyer" tool to assist you.
